title: How does baroque music influence the current music? - Quora

response.answer_text: First of all the system of functional harmony was fully developed during the Baroque. Before 1600 composers were still writing polyphonic music in the church modes (Dorian, Phrygian etc.). After 1600 monophonic music and the major-minor tonal system became more dominant. Rameau wrote his Treatise on Harmony in 1722. The chords of a pop song today are still indebted to the harmonic developments of that era. Classical composers of the twentieth century were often influenced by Bach. Heitor Villa-Lobos combined Brazilian folk music with Baroque in his Bachianas Brasileiras. Dmitri Shostakovich wrote fugues in a neoclassical style. Sometimes songwriters can choose to use instruments or progressions that were typical of the Baroque. In the late 1960s there was a genre Baroque pop. George Harrison’s piano solo in In My Life (1965) was played at double speed to sound a bit like a harpsichord. An actual harpsichord was used in Donovan’s Sunshine Superman (1966) and Van Morrison’s Cyprus Avenue (1968). The introduction to Procol Harum’s A Whiter Shade of Pale, played on a Hammond organ, is reminiscent of Bach’s Air on the G -String. A more recent example is the album Foreverland (2016) by The Divine Comedy. The song Catherine the Great evokes the 18th century with harpsichord and brass instruments. So the influence of Baroque on today’s music is bigger than you might expect.

I’m not a musicologist so I’m not going to embarrass myself by trying to give you a technical answer, but I hear baroque music in modern popular music a lot. Firstly roughly one in ten pop songs is just Pachelbel’s Canon in D. Including the Village People – Go West, and the Pet Shop Boys cover of it and the football chant adaptations of that prevalent throughout English football stadiums (“one nil to the ing-er-land”)… when people turn your music into football chants, the influence can’t go much further.
